subtitle: Hello, I'm Jeffrey Mishlove. You know, back
in the early 1970s when I was a graduate
student in the School of Criminology at
the University of California, as I have
mentioned, as I recall in the very
first "In Presence" segment, I was in agony.
I was working as a volunteer at San
Quentin prison in the psychiatric unit
doing psychotherapy with murderers and
rapists. I felt, as much as that was a
valuable and rewarding experience, that
this is not how I wanted to spend my
life. I wanted to make a shift. I wanted
to immerse myself, not with murderers and
rapists and people suffering from every
form of sociopathy and psychopathology,
but rather to expose myself to the most
creative, insightful, mystical, psychic,
intuitive people that I could find.
With a little help from invisible
resources, I managed to make that
transition back in, I think, about 1972.
So, for the last nearly half a century, I
have managed to live a life in which
I've exposed myself to roughly a
thousand people in the most intimate
kind of one-on-one conversations sharing
with large audiences of tens of
thousands, maybe millions of people
ultimately, the highest wisdom coming
from the mouth of living human beings
that I was able to do. After
half a century of that sort of exposure,
I think a little bit has rubbed off on
me and some of that can be
transmitted simply because it's
something I've been exposed to. A lot
of it is at the non-verbal level. I
don't want to make much of it because as
I've said earlier, I don't consider
myself a guru, except in the sense of the
actual word guru. Gee-You-Are-You. I don't want you
to be me, by any means. But, I'm perfectly
happy and delighted even to be able to
share with you on many different levels,
vibrational levels, intellectual levels,
emotional levels, and the level of humor,
the level of just good-natured presence,
presence with you, which is why I have
called this particular series "In Presence."
So, I can share that. I'm happy to do it,
because it opens me up to receive more,
actually. So, to the extent that those of
you who are out there are able to share
any bit of it through your heart, through
your wisdom, you will benefit as well. The
word that you can spread around, the
wisdom that you find, and not just the
wisdom, but the love that you find, not
just the wisdom and the love but also
the capacity for higher consciousness
that you discover within yourself. To the
extent that you can share that with
others, then you also are able to receive
more. Now, one of my viewers who has made
many comments, and I haven't really
responded much, is a fellow named, or who
calls himself soteriologist. I had
to look up the meaning of soteriology
because I didn't know
in theology it refers to the study
of salvation. He has raised a very
interesting point that I'd like to
address, which is in some of the
exercises that I've shared with you in
the "In Presence" segments, I suggested that
you open yourself up to all of humanity.
Imagine that, all of humanity on this
planet. Or, at times I'm sure I've
suggested, and if I haven't I ought to,
that you open yourself up to the whole
Universe. And why, because that's who you
are, if we're to believe the mystics.
He's pointed out, he says, "No, no, don't
do that. I don't want to open up to all
of that. That's terrible stuff out there.
There's a lot of reasons not to be open
to, at least a good half of it, because
it's negative, because it is
disheartening, because it will pull me
down."
He's arguing that what we should do
is open ourselves up to, one might say, to
the light, to that which is good, to that
which is true and beautiful. That's where
our salvation lies. It's very much, I think
he's arguing along the lines of the Book
of Deuteronomy in the Bible, which says, "I
have set before you a choice. You can
choose life or you can choose death. So,
choose life."
I know I made that choice myself
very dramatically when I stopped my
education in criminology after I got my
master's degree and switched over with
great effort and great struggle to the
study of parapsychology, higher
consciousness as I conceived of it
in my own way at the time, because I had
the good fortune of being able to design
my own doctoral degree program. Now,
there's a paradox there. There's a
paradox. How can one be one with the
Universe, open to the whole Universe,
one with humanity, one with every
precious human soul, and at the same time
not come under the influence of all the
negativity that is out there? I guess
you'd have to say it's a subtle trick
each of us will learn to do it if we are
successful in our own way. I guess I
can say a few little things about it. One
is that I'm something of a Taoist by
nature. I've designed the rainbow
yin yang logo which you see in every
episode of "In Presence" and the New
Thinking Allowed series. One of the
principles of the rainbow yin yang,
obviously, is that there is no such thing
as absolute good or absolute evil. Every
good thing has a little bit of
negativity at least attached to it and
the most evil things that you can
imagine, well some good comes out of them.
But, it goes even a little deeper than
that.
Consider this. Let me put it this way and
I think my friend soteriologist may
agree with me here. I know we disagree on
an awful lot of things, but I want you to
know that I read your comments and
I appreciate them. Some people have
criticized you for being a bit negative
on the comment section and you
responded, I think appropriately, by
saying you think I might appreciate some
criticism. And indeed I do. If one
considers, as my friend Jim Driscoll does,
who I've interviewed about Shakespeare
and about tragedy and about the nature
of evil, that there are revelations in
the Western intellectual cannon, and these
revelations come not exclusively from
Biblical sources or Abrahamic sources,
sometimes revelations come through the
great literary figures of our culture,
the great writers from Dante, from Milton,
from Shakespeare, that these great
writers reveal to us the depths of the
human spirit and even the depths of God,
the depths of the divine. What we
see in these great writers is that they
have an ability to understand not just
the goodness of the human soul but also
the negative side. They expose themselves
to it. Nobody can write more eloquently
about evil than Shakespeare or Milton or
Dante or other great writers. So, to be
able to understand the depths to which
the human soul can sink is what makes a
great writer.
Not that everybody viewing this video
expects to be a great writer, but don't
we all expect in our own way to achieve
a measure of wisdom? And doesn't wisdom
to some degree imply an understanding of
the folly, the flaws, the hatred, the
negativity, the anguish,
the frustration, and sometimes even the
evil that the human spirit is capable of?
Isn't that important for us to know? I
don't think I would be the person I am
today if I hadn't spent those months
inside the psychiatric unit of San
Quentin prison in intimate conversation
with murderers and rapists. It's not that
I advocate becoming a person like that
or opening yourself up to behaving the
way they behave. Certainly not. I think
I've emphasized over and over again the
words of Rudolf Steiner, the great
Austrian mystic who said, "Take two steps
toward developing your own character
before you take one step toward power or
knowledge." Still, it's important to
recognize that while we don't wish to
behave like every negative person that
we see out there or even any of them,
we can't numb ourselves, we
can't wall ourselves off from that. I
think we need to be open to experiencing,
especially the pain, the frustration,
the anguish, the sadness and sorrow
that's out there in the world. It's good
not to wall ourselves off from that.
I have to say, even though I really do
make an effort to be a compassionate
person, that tendency of the human
nervous system to go numb is very real.
It's out of that numbness that great
evil can occur. In fact, I think the worst
evils that have taken place in the
history of this planet have been done in
the name of fighting evil, done in the
name of goodness. That's the paradox.
So, we need to be open to what's going on,
eyes wide open, but always with a
direction towards the highest, the best,
as Plato once pointed out: seek truth,
see goodness, seek justice, seek beauty.
Be open to the wholeness because
that wholeness is ultimately who we are.
We are children of the universe. We were
born out of this whole universe. If it
wasn't for the entire universe, we
wouldn't be here at all.
I'll leave you with that thought.
Thank you once again so much for being
with me.
